author: Craig Adeyanju
title: Starbucks Introduces Gluten-Free and Vegan Food Items
text:
Starbucks Introduces Gluten-Free and Vegan Food Items (SBUX) By Craig Adeyanju | March 22, 2017 — 1:33 PM EDT 
Although Starbucks Corp. ( SBUX ) is known mostly for its coffee and related drinks, there are some changes in store for its food menu which they hope will bring some attention. (See also: Starbucks Vs. Dunkin' Donuts: Comparing Business Models .) 
The coffee chain, in a March 21 press release, said it has added gluten-free and vegan food items to its menu. Some of the items include a gluten free smoked Canadian bacon sandwich, a sprouted grain bagel, lemon chiffon yogurt and Starbucks organic avocado spread. 
The gluten free sandwich is “prepared in a certified gluten-free environment and sealed into its own oven-safe parchment bag to avoid any cross-contamination,” said Starbucks. With this move, SBUX is looking to appeal to the growing population of consumers who believe gluten isn’t good for them. 
A Technavio study said that the market for gluten-free food would grow at a 12 percent annual rate through 2021, presenting SBUX with an opportunity to benefit from the growth. 
Starbucks isn’t the first to offer gluten-free food items in the fast food industry. Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc. ( CMG ), for instance, has a list of allergens and special diets that lists corresponding menu items safe for sufferers of those conditions to consume; only one of the items on the list contains gluten. Dunkin’ Brands Group Inc. ( DNKN ) also tested gluten-free donuts in 2013, although it didn’t ultimately launch the gluten-free donuts in the end. 
The fact that Dunkin’ didn’t roll out gluten-free donuts speaks to the difficulty that comes with selling gluten-free food, Technomic Chief Insights Officer Darren Tristano told CNBC, adding that Starbucks’ gluten-free initiative won’t be a revenue driver for now. The initiative is more likely to only foster customer retention for Starbucks, Tristano said. 
Food accounts for 20 percent of Starbucks’ total sales , according to Starbucks COO Kevin Johnson, who will succeed Howard Schultz as the CEO next month.
